title: The Framing of Decisions and the Psychology of Choice
description: The psychological principles that govern the perception of decision problems and the evaluation of probabilities and outcomes produce predictable shifts of preference when the same problem is framed in different ways. Reversals of preference are demonstrated in choices regarding monetary outcomes, both hypothetical and real, and in questions pertaining to the loss of human lives. The effects of frames on preferences are compared to the effects of perspectives on perceptual appearance. The dependence of preferences on the formulation of decision problems is a significant concern for the theory of rational choice....

findings.main_hypothesis: Choices involving gains are often risk averse and choices involving losses are often risk taking; framing the same objective outcomes as gains or losses will reverse preference.
When facing concurrent decisions, individuals frame choices narrowly, leading to the selection of a combined portfolio that is stochastically dominated by an alternative portfolio.
A reduction in the probability of an outcome has more impact when the outcome was initially certain than when it was merely probable (Pseudocertainty effect).
The willingness to purchase a ticket depends on whether a prior loss is posted to the same psychological account (the ticket) or a different account (general cash).
People evaluate price savings in a minimal account (relative to the item price) rather than an inclusive account (total purchase price).
